global_attributes.title: Gliders in the Gulf Stream
global_attributes.acknowledgement: This project is funded by National Science Foundation, Office of Naval Research, NOAA Ocean Observing and Monitoring Division, Eastman, WHOI
global_attributes.contributor_name: Robert Todd, Brechner Owens, Guilherme Castelao
global_attributes.contributor_role: Principal Investigator, Principal Investigator, Database Manager
global_attributes.summary: The overarching goal of this project is to collect high resolution transects across the Gulf Stream. Though the speed of the Gulf Stream greatly exceeds the speed of a glider, gliders can be flown across the current as they are advected downstream. Missions prior to 2015 were conducted downstream (northeast) of Cape Hatteras, primarily between Cape Cod and Bermuda; missions since 2015 begin in Miami, FL and are planned to end on the New England continental shelf. During a typical 100-day mission between Miami and Cape Cod, a single glider completes 6-10 crossings of the Gulf Stream, returning approximately 800 profiles to the shallower of the sea floor or 1000 m. The current operational goal is to maintain at least one glider in the Gulf Stream at all times. Additional plots of these data are available at http://gliders.whoi.edu.
global_attributes.references:
Todd, R. E., D. L. Rudnick, J. T. Sherman, W. B. Owens, and L. George, 2016: Absolute velocity estimates from autonomous underwater gliders equipped with Doppler current profilers. Journal of Atmospheric and Oceanic Technology, in press; doi: 10.1175/JTECH-D-16-0156.1
 Todd, R. E., Owens, W. B., & Rudnick, D. L. (2016). Potential vorticity structure in the North Atlantic western boundary current from underwater glider observations. Journal of Physical Oceanography, 46(1), 327-348.; doi: 10.1175/JPO-D-15-0112.1
